description: *** Updated to reflect changes to the exam effective Jan 2016 *** The Project Management Professional (PMP) certification from the Project Management Institute is the leading certification for individuals working as a project manager. The certification combines breadth of knowledge with extensive pre-requisites to ensure that candidates who successfully complete the exam are competent and well versed in the various tools and techniques used by successful project managers. The certificate is targeted at individuals with over five years of experience working as a project manager and seeking to validate their knowledge and experience through becoming certified. Individuals without five years of documented experience should consider the Certified Associate of Project Management (CAPM) certification. At ITProTV, our project management show is designed to prepare the viewer for both exams.
descriptionMD: Updated to reflect changes to the exam effective Jan 2016. The Project Management Professional (PMP® ) certification from the Project Management Institute is the leading certification for individuals working as a project manager. The certification combines breadth of knowledge with extensive pre-requisites to ensure that candidates who successfully complete the exam are competent and well versed in the various tools and techniques used by successful project managers. The certificate is targeted at individuals with over five years of experience working as a project manager and seeking to validate their knowledge and experience through becoming certified. Individuals without five years of documented experience should consider the Certified Associate of Project Management (CAPM®) certification. At ITProTV, our project management show is designed to prepare the viewer for both exams. PMP® and CAPM® are registered trademarks of the Project Management Institute.
name: Project Management Professional
subtitle: Project Management Certification

episodes.description:
The Project Management Professional certification from the Project Management Institute is an advanced level certification that requires not only a written exam from the candidate but also verifiable non-overlapping field experience and continuing education.  It is the most significant industry recognized certification for Project Managers worldwide.  Project Managers with this certification are in high demand because it validates the excellence of knowledge, experience and ability in Project Management Leadership.

The following download link is to a Zip file containing the templates and formulas used in the episodes. 

https://itprotv-notes-bucket.s3.amazonaws.com/ITProTV_PMP_Templates.zip
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:04,767
[SOUND] In this video,
we're gonna take a look at

2
00:00:04,767 --> 00:00:10,226
the project management
professionals certification

3
00:00:10,226 --> 00:00:15,220
from the Project Management Institute,
or PMI.

4
00:00:15,220 --> 00:00:18,270
We get [LAUGH] a little [LAUGH]
Acronym soup on this one.

5
00:00:19,590 --> 00:00:22,192
The The PMI's PMP certification.

6
00:00:22,192 --> 00:00:24,430
[LAUGH] It's a bit of a mouthful.

7
00:00:24,430 --> 00:00:29,710
It is a industry recognized project
management certification, and if you're

8
00:00:29,710 --> 00:00:33,430
not familiar with project management
in general, well, let me tell you.

9
00:00:33,430 --> 00:00:36,480
It's a hot button issue with
a lot of organizations.

10
00:00:36,480 --> 00:00:40,380
We're starting to see more and more
companies move towards formalized project

11
00:00:40,380 --> 00:00:44,520
management frameworks, and there's
a number of frameworks that are out there,

12
00:00:44,520 --> 00:00:45,790
companies that are free to pick and

13
00:00:45,790 --> 00:00:49,880
choose whatever they want, but PMI,
the Project Management Institute,

14
00:00:49,880 --> 00:00:54,330
they are a non-profit organization
that was formed over 20 years ago.

15
00:00:54,330 --> 00:00:55,730
They've been around a while.

16
00:00:55,730 --> 00:01:01,510
And they're idea was hey, if you learn
how to manage a project for one company,

17
00:01:01,510 --> 00:01:05,160
and then you go to a second company you
haven't to start over from scratch.

18
00:01:05,160 --> 00:01:08,110
There's a lot of stuff that's
done that's the same, and so

19
00:01:08,110 --> 00:01:10,300
they set out to create a framework.

20
00:01:10,300 --> 00:01:14,980
A collection of processes that you
can use, to help manage projects.

21
00:01:14,980 --> 00:01:19,210
The idea being that whether you're
in construction, or medical,

22
00:01:19,210 --> 00:01:22,630
or IT, or whatever,
that a project is a project.

23
00:01:22,630 --> 00:01:26,690
They all have the same fundamental
methods for managing them.

24
00:01:26,690 --> 00:01:28,270
And ensuring success.

25
00:01:28,270 --> 00:01:31,980
So they put all that
together into one big giant

26
00:01:31,980 --> 00:01:34,590
book called the Project Management Body
of Knowledge.

27
00:01:34,590 --> 00:01:36,458
And it is a big book,
what is it now, Ronnie?

28
00:01:36,458 --> 00:01:39,110
It's like.
Over 600, 700 pages.

29
00:01:39,110 --> 00:01:40,170
Yeah, it's massive.

30
00:01:40,170 --> 00:01:42,790
Yeah.
And what they did is, they just took ways

31
00:01:42,790 --> 00:01:46,840
that people were managing projects,
they made them a little more generic so

32
00:01:46,840 --> 00:01:50,930
they applied to any industry and
put them together in this big book.

33
00:01:50,930 --> 00:01:54,700
And the idea is that if companies want
to implement formal project management,

34
00:01:54,700 --> 00:01:58,680
instead of starting from scratch,
they can just grab the PMI's model,

35
00:01:58,680 --> 00:01:59,680
their framework.

36
00:01:59,680 --> 00:02:03,110
And you don't have to do the whole thing;
it's often times overkill for small and

37
00:02:03,110 --> 00:02:04,260
medium businesses.

38
00:02:04,260 --> 00:02:08,530
You can pick and choice the components
that you want that are appropriate for

39
00:02:08,530 --> 00:02:10,840
your organization that help
you manage and, ultimately,

40
00:02:10,840 --> 00:02:13,650
be successful in the project.

41
00:02:13,650 --> 00:02:14,450
It's really cool.

42
00:02:14,450 --> 00:02:15,350
It's really flexible.

43
00:02:15,350 --> 00:02:18,470
That's kind of a nice thing to have
available and that's made it really

44
00:02:18,470 --> 00:02:23,520
attractive to a lot of companies,
in the United States the PMP or

45
00:02:23,520 --> 00:02:29,330
the PMI framework is the most common
standardized form of project management.

46
00:02:29,330 --> 00:02:31,030
There's other ones out there.

47
00:02:31,030 --> 00:02:34,450
The whole ISO 9000 series or
20,000 series.

48
00:02:34,450 --> 00:02:37,142
You got the prints two.

49
00:02:37,142 --> 00:02:40,380
There's other methods of project
management that are out there.

50
00:02:40,380 --> 00:02:43,480
But in the United States,
the PMI method is the most common.

51
00:02:44,490 --> 00:02:46,040
The other ones aren't bad.

52
00:02:46,040 --> 00:02:48,660
In fact, often times they're very similar.

53
00:02:48,660 --> 00:02:52,240
They kind of work together, they may
just use different terminology and

54
00:02:52,240 --> 00:02:52,990
things like that.

55
00:02:52,990 --> 00:02:54,070
So be aware of that.

56
00:02:54,070 --> 00:02:54,960
But here in the US,

57
00:02:54,960 --> 00:03:00,180
PMI's, their's is really kind of
the one that's the go-to guy, right?

58
00:03:00,180 --> 00:03:02,790
That's where the PMP comes in.

59
00:03:02,790 --> 00:03:08,060
PMP or Project Management Professional, is
a certification that designates that you

60
00:03:08,060 --> 00:03:13,610
have the skills and knowledge, to manage
a project using all of the tools and

61
00:03:13,610 --> 00:03:17,080
processes and
all the stuff that PMI gives us.

62
00:03:17,080 --> 00:03:18,360
That framework.

63
00:03:18,360 --> 00:03:22,931
And if you are a PMP certified project
manager, when you go to a company and

64
00:03:22,931 --> 00:03:27,280
you give them your resume they can
look at and they can say, all right,

65
00:03:27,280 --> 00:03:32,147
this guy already knows how to manage a
project the certain way, how they can get

66
00:03:32,147 --> 00:03:36,563
in there and do this and it would be
a standard method so that if we have.

67
00:03:36,563 --> 00:03:39,810
Other project managers come in they will
be able to understand what's going on.

68
00:03:39,810 --> 00:03:42,400
I know that's a problem that
I've bumped in too before.

69
00:03:42,400 --> 00:03:44,400
Where you go to work somewhere and

70
00:03:44,400 --> 00:03:48,290
they have 12 different project managers,
if they're all managing projects different

71
00:03:48,290 --> 00:03:51,660
ways it becomes really difficult to
monitor and exchange information.

72
00:03:53,402 --> 00:03:53,930
All right,

73
00:03:53,930 --> 00:03:58,790
with the PMI if we want to become a PMP,
a Project Managing Professional.

74
00:03:58,790 --> 00:04:03,330
Step one on our journey, really needs
to be going to the project management

75
00:04:03,330 --> 00:04:08,500
professional, or to the PMI website,
and downloading the PMP handbook.

76
00:04:08,500 --> 00:04:11,570
The PMP handbook really summarizes
everything that we need to know about

77
00:04:11,570 --> 00:04:14,120
the certification, and
we'll go over it briefly in this video.

78
00:04:14,120 --> 00:04:16,660
But I encourage you guys
to read it thoroughly,

79
00:04:16,660 --> 00:04:19,700
especially if you're going
to pursue the certification.

80
00:04:19,700 --> 00:04:24,070
If you go to PMI.org that's the website,
PMI.org.

81
00:04:24,070 --> 00:04:28,590
You'll see on that site,
there's a link for certification.

82
00:04:28,590 --> 00:04:33,120
And if we go into that certification link,
it'll take you in here where you can

83
00:04:33,120 --> 00:04:36,760
start to see information about the PMP and
other certifications.

84
00:04:36,760 --> 00:04:38,200
There's a bunch of them over here.

85
00:04:39,360 --> 00:04:42,940
CAPM, PMP, PGMP and so on.

86
00:04:42,940 --> 00:04:46,180
The industry leader,
the one everybody knows is the PMP.

87
00:04:46,180 --> 00:04:49,420
And CAPM,
let's talk about that just a little bit.

88
00:04:49,420 --> 00:04:52,520
That's the Certified Associate
in Project Management

89
00:04:52,520 --> 00:04:54,110
vs Project Management Professional.

90
00:04:55,360 --> 00:05:01,160
PMP is designed for project managers,
people who managing projects as their job.

91
00:05:01,160 --> 00:05:04,080
They need to be experts in every
aspect of project management.

92
00:05:05,490 --> 00:05:09,590
CAPM, that is somebody who's
not project manager, but

93
00:05:09,590 --> 00:05:11,660
works in a project environment.

94
00:05:11,660 --> 00:05:14,690
They're a project team member or
maybe they're an accountant or

95
00:05:14,690 --> 00:05:18,360
scheduling assistant or somebody like
that, who is not the project manager, but

96
00:05:18,360 --> 00:05:21,910
it's operating in that world
on a constant basis, so

97
00:05:21,910 --> 00:05:25,210
they need to be familiar with
the various tools and techniques and

98
00:05:25,210 --> 00:05:28,260
all of the other different things that
are involved inside of managing a project.

99
00:05:29,280 --> 00:05:33,630
Now, if you're on the fence between
the two, let me tell you this,

100
00:05:33,630 --> 00:05:38,510
they both have test questions that
pull from the same exact information.

101
00:05:38,510 --> 00:05:42,930
The way you study for CAPM,
is the same way that you study for PMP.

102
00:05:44,000 --> 00:05:45,840
As long as you meet the qualifications,

103
00:05:45,840 --> 00:05:50,190
almost everyone should go for the PMP, but
not everyone meets those qualifications.

104
00:05:50,190 --> 00:05:52,500
Now, what are those qualifications?

105
00:05:52,500 --> 00:05:54,910
That's what we can find in the handbook.

106
00:05:54,910 --> 00:05:59,690
I'm gonna browse to the PMP page here and,
you'll see on the PMP page,

107
00:05:59,690 --> 00:06:03,510
right up at the top right here,
we've got the PMP handbook.

108
00:06:03,510 --> 00:06:07,550
And I can just click on that,
to get into the handbook.

109
00:06:07,550 --> 00:06:08,340
It's a PDF.

110
00:06:08,340 --> 00:06:10,640
So you can download it and save it.

111
00:06:10,640 --> 00:06:16,030
And I know in the address bar
up here it shows an ashx or

112
00:06:16,030 --> 00:06:18,810
whatever extension, but it is a PDF file.

113
00:06:18,810 --> 00:06:24,200
And it lays out all the information
you need about the certification.

114
00:06:24,200 --> 00:06:29,040
What it is, who really qualifies for
it, how you can sign up for

115
00:06:29,040 --> 00:06:32,000
it, where you can take it,
all of that information is here.

116
00:06:32,000 --> 00:06:33,710
This is something that
is really important,

117
00:06:33,710 --> 00:06:36,180
every single page has
important data in it.

118
00:06:36,180 --> 00:06:39,690
All right, now I don't want to
focus on the whole thing though,

119
00:06:39,690 --> 00:06:41,040
we'd be here all day.

120
00:06:41,040 --> 00:06:44,400
But let's get to our requirements,
here we go.

121
00:06:45,760 --> 00:06:49,860
This is kind of laying out
the process we need to follow

122
00:06:49,860 --> 00:06:52,140
if we want to become certified.

123
00:06:52,140 --> 00:06:55,280
And basically,
it goes through a few things.

124
00:06:55,280 --> 00:06:59,290
You send in an application,
you have to apply to take the exam,

125
00:06:59,290 --> 00:07:01,140
you can't just go and take the exam.

126
00:07:01,140 --> 00:07:05,230
And in that application,
you have to designate you're experience.

127
00:07:05,230 --> 00:07:09,720
The information that you have gained over
the years as far as where you worked,

128
00:07:09,720 --> 00:07:10,240
what you've done.

129
00:07:10,240 --> 00:07:13,080
You have to meet certain
experience levels.

130
00:07:13,080 --> 00:07:16,100
And once you meet that,
you can then take the exam.

131
00:07:16,100 --> 00:07:18,220
And so that's kind of what
they're highlighting here.

132
00:07:18,220 --> 00:07:21,580
But they actually don't break
down the true requirements there.

133
00:07:21,580 --> 00:07:24,390
Let's find it, here, all right,

134
00:07:24,390 --> 00:07:29,360
if you want to get your PMP,
you have to meet certain requirements,

135
00:07:29,360 --> 00:07:32,070
which is what they're listing
right here on this screen.

136
00:07:32,070 --> 00:07:34,600
And, where's my little zoom in icon?

137
00:07:34,600 --> 00:07:36,850
Apparently I don't get that.

138
00:07:36,850 --> 00:07:40,130
There we go, so
what you'll see is it is different

139
00:07:40,130 --> 00:07:42,760
if you have a bachelor's degree or
if you don't.

140
00:07:42,760 --> 00:07:47,860
If you have a college diploma, or the
equivalent in your country, if you have

141
00:07:47,860 --> 00:07:54,260
a bachelor's degree, then what you
need is three years or 36 months.

142
00:07:54,260 --> 00:07:57,654
Of unique none overlapping
experience in project management.

143
00:07:57,654 --> 00:08:00,860
That means, if you are managing
three projects at the same time,

144
00:08:00,860 --> 00:08:03,029
you only get credit for
one of them, right?

145
00:08:03,029 --> 00:08:10,634
So you've got to show that you've acquired
4,500 hours as a project manager.

146
00:08:10,634 --> 00:08:14,415
And they actually qualify it a little
more there, spent leading and

147
00:08:14,415 --> 00:08:16,090
directing the project.

148
00:08:16,090 --> 00:08:19,580
Not necessarily being the project manager,

149
00:08:19,580 --> 00:08:23,010
you might have been a team
lead inside of the project.

150
00:08:23,010 --> 00:08:26,440
That's like a sub project manager.

151
00:08:26,440 --> 00:08:28,130
So that counts, too.

152
00:08:28,130 --> 00:08:30,040
But you'll see 4,500 hours there.

153
00:08:30,040 --> 00:08:33,710
If you don't have a degree,
it's 7,500 hours.

154
00:08:33,710 --> 00:08:38,000
7,500 hours over 5 years, non-overlapping.

155
00:08:38,000 --> 00:08:39,370
So in order to get the PMP,

156
00:08:39,370 --> 00:08:43,300
you really need to be a project
manager already, right?

157
00:08:43,300 --> 00:08:44,420
What if you're not?

158
00:08:44,420 --> 00:08:45,920
Well that's what the CAPM is for.

159
00:08:45,920 --> 00:08:49,100
The CAPM, the Certified Associate
in Project Management,

160
00:08:49,100 --> 00:08:53,490
it covers the same material,
you study the same way for it, but

161
00:08:53,490 --> 00:08:56,610
it doesn't have
the requirement of experience.

162
00:08:56,610 --> 00:08:59,202
You don't have to show that
you have 4,000 or 7,000, or

163
00:08:59,202 --> 00:09:01,675
whatever hours of experience
when you do the CAPM, all right.

164
00:09:01,675 --> 00:09:09,465
And then, after that, both of them
require 35 hours of education.

165
00:09:09,465 --> 00:09:14,402
You have to have attended 35 hours
of training in project management.

166
00:09:14,402 --> 00:09:16,312
Now, not necessarily PMP classes.

167
00:09:16,312 --> 00:09:19,682
Maybe you've done Microsoft project or

168
00:09:21,412 --> 00:09:25,670
Timberline training, or something like
that that pertain to your industry.

169
00:09:25,670 --> 00:09:27,110
Well, that counts too, right?

170
00:09:27,110 --> 00:09:30,460
So you just have to submit that you
attended those hours and those count.

171
00:09:30,460 --> 00:09:33,230
So you need 35 contact
hours of formal education.

172
00:09:33,230 --> 00:09:36,610
All right, so
those are the main requirements.

173
00:09:36,610 --> 00:09:39,030
If you meet those requirements,

174
00:09:39,030 --> 00:09:44,910
then you can take pass and
become certified with the PMP.

175
00:09:44,910 --> 00:09:47,550
If you don't meet these,
your application will be declined,

176
00:09:47,550 --> 00:09:49,350
you won't be allowed to take the exam.

177
00:09:49,350 --> 00:09:52,830
So that's the first thing
that we need to be aware of.

178
00:09:52,830 --> 00:09:55,440
Next, well then we're ready to certify,
right?

179
00:09:55,440 --> 00:09:57,620
And that's what this chart
back here was showing,

180
00:09:57,620 --> 00:10:02,210
is you submit your application that shows
that you met those requirements, right?

181
00:10:02,210 --> 00:10:03,090
So you basically

182
00:10:03,090 --> 00:10:05,890
let them know that you meet all
the requirements that were listed.

183
00:10:05,890 --> 00:10:09,780
Then after that they review
your application, and

184
00:10:09,780 --> 00:10:14,660
it says five days for the review,
it's usually much, much shorter, right?

185
00:10:14,660 --> 00:10:17,190
It's been a long time since I did mine.

186
00:10:17,190 --> 00:10:19,640
Mine I think took maybe two days.

187
00:10:19,640 --> 00:10:20,710
Then you have to pay.

188
00:10:20,710 --> 00:10:22,700
You do have to pay for the exam.

189
00:10:22,700 --> 00:10:24,588
They gotta get paid.

190
00:10:24,588 --> 00:10:28,730
[LAUGH] So, you have to pay for the exam
and then you go ahead and take it,

191
00:10:28,730 --> 00:10:29,850
and hopefully pass.

192
00:10:29,850 --> 00:10:35,740
Now once you pass the exam and
notice here from payment to test,

193
00:10:35,740 --> 00:10:38,870
you have to take the test within
one year of when you paid.

194
00:10:38,870 --> 00:10:40,850
So that's pretty important.

195
00:10:40,850 --> 00:10:45,250
If you don't, then you lose the money,
and you gotta pay again,

196
00:10:45,250 --> 00:10:48,170
they don't do a refund on that.

197
00:10:48,170 --> 00:10:49,730
Once you become certified,

198
00:10:49,730 --> 00:10:54,420
you're then in the certification cycle,
you have to renew every three years.

199
00:10:54,420 --> 00:10:57,790
And you can renew one
of two different ways.

200
00:10:57,790 --> 00:11:00,110
Method one is to retake the exam, right?

201
00:11:00,110 --> 00:11:03,130
But if you're like me, once you take
it you don't wanna take it again.

202
00:11:03,130 --> 00:11:04,680
It's a long exam.

203
00:11:04,680 --> 00:11:08,560
So method two is to do
continuing education.

204
00:11:08,560 --> 00:11:13,130
You continue to learn,
you attend webinars, you attend classes,

205
00:11:13,130 --> 00:11:16,910
you get what are called professional
development units, or PDUs, and

206
00:11:16,910 --> 00:11:21,370
you have to acquire 60 PDUs or
basically 60 hours every three years.

207
00:11:22,610 --> 00:11:26,450
Now, I'll talk about something in a minute
which is an easy way to get PDUs.

208
00:11:26,450 --> 00:11:28,940
So they're not hard to get, and
they can actually be done very,

209
00:11:28,940 --> 00:11:31,940
very inexpensively, but
they do need to be done.

210
00:11:31,940 --> 00:11:37,630
So, for example, I'm on my second
renewal cycle with PMI and so

211
00:11:37,630 --> 00:11:42,341
for me, I am continually doing activities
to get more PDUs, it's important.

212
00:11:43,740 --> 00:11:47,450
Aright, so as long as that's done,
you stay certified and

213
00:11:47,450 --> 00:11:51,050
you can be certified for life,
as long as you continue to do your PDUs.

214
00:11:51,050 --> 00:11:55,550
If you ever don't if you just stop,
you go on a one year suspension, so

215
00:11:55,550 --> 00:11:59,280
you have a chance to become current,
but if you don't do it then,

216
00:11:59,280 --> 00:12:01,560
then you've got to go and
pass the exam again.

217
00:12:01,560 --> 00:12:05,040
So that's kind of the process
that they follow.

218
00:12:05,040 --> 00:12:11,940
So the exam itself is administered through
Sylvan Centers in the United States and

219
00:12:11,940 --> 00:12:14,160
other countries, because it's
administered in different places.

220
00:12:14,160 --> 00:12:18,779
So, definitely read through the handbook
to find out where it's offered for

221
00:12:18,779 --> 00:12:20,460
your country.

222
00:12:20,460 --> 00:12:23,290
Then, the exam itself,
let me just find the price here.

223
00:12:23,290 --> 00:12:24,750
Here we go.

224
00:12:24,750 --> 00:12:28,930
For the exam,
if you are doing the computer based

225
00:12:30,340 --> 00:12:35,980
testing, which is the standard method,
you'll see the exam is $405 for

226
00:12:35,980 --> 00:12:41,600
PMI members, and it's $555 for
non PMI members.

227
00:12:42,610 --> 00:12:43,775
What's this membership stuff?

228
00:12:43,775 --> 00:12:48,770
PMI.org is a nonprofit organization,

229
00:12:48,770 --> 00:12:53,200
and anyone, without limits,
can join the PMI.

230
00:12:53,200 --> 00:12:57,570
So you can become a member of the Project
Management Institute today, right now.

231
00:12:57,570 --> 00:13:00,100
You can go to their website,
sign up and join the PMI.

232
00:13:02,580 --> 00:13:03,400
It's a great service.

233
00:13:03,400 --> 00:13:08,070
I've been a PMI member for six years now,
five years, something like that,

234
00:13:08,070 --> 00:13:11,700
and you get access to free webinars,
which count for PDUs.

235
00:13:11,700 --> 00:13:12,200
Right.

236
00:13:12,200 --> 00:13:17,600
I get a good three PDUs a month
just as part of my PMI membership.

237
00:13:17,600 --> 00:13:20,790
You get access to articles online.

238
00:13:20,790 --> 00:13:24,120
You get access to communities where you
can talk to other people that are in

239
00:13:24,120 --> 00:13:25,180
your industry.

240
00:13:25,180 --> 00:13:30,076
You also get a free copy of the PMBOK,
the Project Management Body of Knowledge,

241
00:13:30,076 --> 00:13:31,021
that big book.

242
00:13:31,021 --> 00:13:32,850
Right.
That 700 page book you get a free copy.

243
00:13:32,850 --> 00:13:33,490
It's a PDF.

244
00:13:33,490 --> 00:13:34,320
It's a digital copy.

245
00:13:34,320 --> 00:13:36,855
But, believe me,
you wouldn't want the paper one.

246
00:13:36,855 --> 00:13:39,100
[LAUGH] So,
you get that as part of your membership.

247
00:13:39,100 --> 00:13:40,900
So a lot of good value there.

248
00:13:40,900 --> 00:13:43,750
But another value is
the discount on the exam.

249
00:13:43,750 --> 00:13:46,170
That's $150 off the exam.

250
00:13:46,170 --> 00:13:52,150
Well, it costs $129 per year
to be a member of the PMI.

251
00:13:52,150 --> 00:13:58,710
So you pay $129 to save $150,
it pays for itself.

252
00:13:58,710 --> 00:14:01,100
And you get a year membership out of it.

253
00:14:01,100 --> 00:14:05,290
Now, PMI does that on purpose because
they want you to stay a member.

254
00:14:05,290 --> 00:14:09,190
People like me continue to stay
a member because I get value out of it.

255
00:14:09,190 --> 00:14:12,860
But here getting ready for
the exam you get two big things.

256
00:14:12,860 --> 00:14:14,830
One, you get the discount so
it pays for itself.

257
00:14:14,830 --> 00:14:15,900
Why not do it?

258
00:14:15,900 --> 00:14:21,140
And two, you get a copy of the PMBOK,
which is what the test is based on.

259
00:14:21,140 --> 00:14:23,750
The PMP exam is full of questions

260
00:14:23,750 --> 00:14:27,300
pulled straight from
the Project Manager Body of Knowledge.

261
00:14:27,300 --> 00:14:29,420
So it's almost like having the answer key.

262
00:14:29,420 --> 00:14:32,780
Now granted, it's a 700 page answer
key that you can't take with you.

263
00:14:32,780 --> 00:14:35,390
But [LAUGH] the information is there.

264
00:14:35,390 --> 00:14:39,590
It's worth it,
you do want to become a member.

265
00:14:39,590 --> 00:14:44,930
You'll see right there that cost, the $400
and $555, depending on which way you go,

266
00:14:44,930 --> 00:14:48,940
that's how your price
is gonna be determined.

267
00:14:48,940 --> 00:14:54,020
Now if you do not pass the first time,
you can repeat the exam.

268
00:14:54,020 --> 00:14:56,880
And when you repeat,
they do give you a discount.

269
00:14:56,880 --> 00:15:00,313
So you'll see members are $275,

270
00:15:00,313 --> 00:15:05,795
non-members are $375, so
a bit of a difference there.

271
00:15:05,795 --> 00:15:08,555
So that's kind of the exam cost.

272
00:15:08,555 --> 00:15:12,475
We sign up for the exam and
we go and take it,

273
00:15:12,475 --> 00:15:18,065
at whatever testing provider is
available in the region that we're in.

274
00:15:18,065 --> 00:15:21,115
From there, you're ready to take the exam.

275
00:15:21,115 --> 00:15:28,460
The PMP exam itself, it's 175 questions,
I'm sorry, it's kind of confusing.

276
00:15:28,460 --> 00:15:29,480
It's 200 questions.

277
00:15:30,600 --> 00:15:31,580
Only 175 actually count
towards your score.

278
00:15:31,580 --> 00:15:38,603
The other 25,
they're kind of like beta questions.

279
00:15:38,603 --> 00:15:39,705
They're trying you out.

280
00:15:39,705 --> 00:15:41,180
They call them pre-test.

281
00:15:41,180 --> 00:15:45,970
To see if they work, if the questions are
good if people are getting them right at

282
00:15:45,970 --> 00:15:49,500
the average amount that they look for,
then those will become real questions for

283
00:15:49,500 --> 00:15:50,590
other people.

284
00:15:50,590 --> 00:15:51,350
If they don't work,

285
00:15:51,350 --> 00:15:55,000
if a lot of people are getting them wrong,
then PMI will remove them.

286
00:15:55,000 --> 00:16:00,460
The thing is, they don't tell you
which questions are pretest and

287
00:16:00,460 --> 00:16:02,224
which ones aren't.

288
00:16:02,224 --> 00:16:03,710
So when you take the exam
you get 200 questions.

289
00:16:03,710 --> 00:16:05,009
You have to treat them
all as if they were real.

290
00:16:05,009 --> 00:16:06,948
You don't know which 25 don't count.

291
00:16:06,948 --> 00:16:14,444
So, while it's a 200 question exam,
only 175 actually count to your score.

292
00:16:14,444 --> 00:16:16,841
All right?
It is a four hour exam, and

293
00:16:16,841 --> 00:16:21,898
if you're like me,
I went to three hours and 59 minutes.

294
00:16:21,898 --> 00:16:24,970
I mean,
I went right to the end of that exam.

295
00:16:24,970 --> 00:16:26,660
It just depends on the person, though.

296
00:16:26,660 --> 00:16:29,212
I've heard of people getting in and
out of there, in like two hours,

297
00:16:29,212 --> 00:16:29,960
which blew my mind.

298
00:16:29,960 --> 00:16:34,990
But, if you are a focused and
really detail oriented

299
00:16:34,990 --> 00:16:40,320
tester like I am,
you'll take up that whole time.

300
00:16:40,320 --> 00:16:41,988
It's a long one.

301
00:16:41,988 --> 00:16:46,620
One point, I do wanna make is,
you can take breaks during the exam.

302
00:16:46,620 --> 00:16:47,445
Mm-hm.

303
00:16:47,445 --> 00:16:49,095
It says no scheduled breaks [SOUND].

304
00:16:49,095 --> 00:16:52,512
But, you can take your own breaks if you
want, if you need to go to the restroom or

305
00:16:52,512 --> 00:16:53,405
whatever.

306
00:16:53,405 --> 00:16:55,215
But the timer doesn't stop.

307
00:16:55,215 --> 00:16:58,055
When that 4 hour timer starts, it's going.

308
00:16:58,055 --> 00:17:00,825
So, if you take a 15 minute
break to use the restroom,

309
00:17:00,825 --> 00:17:02,465
you just lost 15 minutes on the exam.

310
00:17:02,465 --> 00:17:06,745
So be aware of that, you want to stay
focused and get through the exam.

311
00:17:08,750 --> 00:17:13,900
All right, the exam itself is
pulled right from the PMBOK.

312
00:17:13,900 --> 00:17:15,860
And in the real show,

313
00:17:15,860 --> 00:17:19,300
we're gonna talk about the different
project phases that are out there.

314
00:17:19,300 --> 00:17:21,250
PMI breaks a project into five phases,

315
00:17:21,250 --> 00:17:25,520
and they're just showing here the way that
questions break down percentage wise.

316
00:17:25,520 --> 00:17:29,740
So initiation is 13% of the exam,
and then so on, as it breaks down.

317
00:17:29,740 --> 00:17:34,220
You'll see that executing is probably
the largest portion of the exam, but

318
00:17:34,220 --> 00:17:37,030
planning and monitoring, and
controlling are another big portion.

319
00:17:37,030 --> 00:17:38,250
Everything else is kind
of spread out from there.

320
00:17:41,198 --> 00:17:44,530
All right, and I think that's really
about it that we need from here.

321
00:17:44,530 --> 00:17:45,910
Seems like there was one other thing.

322
00:17:45,910 --> 00:17:49,890
Let me just skim through here real
quick to see if I can spot it.

323
00:17:49,890 --> 00:17:50,840
I mean there's a ton of information.

324
00:17:50,840 --> 00:17:52,720
One of my favorite things about the PMI,

325
00:17:52,720 --> 00:17:57,900
is they post all of their phone
numbers right here in the handbook.

326
00:17:57,900 --> 00:18:01,050
And I've called probably three
times over the years, and

327
00:18:01,050 --> 00:18:04,760
every time,
I got a human being answering the phone.

328
00:18:04,760 --> 00:18:07,150
It's just unheard of,
no computer menu or anything.

329
00:18:07,150 --> 00:18:08,220
I actually got a person.

330
00:18:08,220 --> 00:18:10,170
So, if you ever have
a question on this stuff,

331
00:18:10,170 --> 00:18:13,420
if you're not sure where to sign up or
whatever, just give them a phone call.

332
00:18:13,420 --> 00:18:17,730
All the phone numbers are right there,
in the handbook.

333
00:18:17,730 --> 00:18:20,420
It's a valuable thing to have.

334
00:18:20,420 --> 00:18:20,930
Let's see.

335
00:18:20,930 --> 00:18:22,320
That is for the other stuff.

336
00:18:23,760 --> 00:18:25,590
Yeah, that's the main stuff from here.

337
00:18:25,590 --> 00:18:28,140
Like I said, there is a lot of good
stuff in this handbook though.

338
00:18:28,140 --> 00:18:29,320
So, go and download it.

339
00:18:29,320 --> 00:18:32,560
It is good information for you.

340
00:18:32,560 --> 00:18:34,382
All right, once you become a PMP.

341
00:18:34,382 --> 00:18:38,204
Once you're certified, you've shown
that you have an understanding of,

342
00:18:38,204 --> 00:18:42,120
how the project management
institute's framework functions.

343
00:18:42,120 --> 00:18:44,820
Now, you turn around and
you apply it at your organization.

344
00:18:44,820 --> 00:18:48,070
There's many organizations that require
their project managers to be a PMP

345
00:18:48,070 --> 00:18:52,300
certified PM, and
that's a good thing, in my opinion.

346
00:18:52,300 --> 00:18:53,910
It is really handy.

347
00:18:53,910 --> 00:18:56,102
If you step into a project mid-stream,

348
00:18:56,102 --> 00:18:59,310
like mid-project, if they've been
following the PMI framework, it's

349
00:18:59,310 --> 00:19:03,380
super easy to get jump started, get in
there, and start working in the project.

350
00:19:03,380 --> 00:19:07,260
If they've just done fly by, the seat of
their pants, make up their own stuff,

351
00:19:07,260 --> 00:19:10,940
it's really difficult to get up to speed,
and make sure everything's in place.

352
00:19:10,940 --> 00:19:13,475
And that's one of the things
that the PMI framework does.

353
00:19:13,475 --> 00:19:14,420
Mm-hm.

354
00:19:14,420 --> 00:19:15,790
So.

355
00:19:15,790 --> 00:19:16,360
All right.
Ronnie,

356
00:19:16,360 --> 00:19:20,610
I think that's a pretty good summary
of the PMP, and kinda what's involved.

357
00:19:20,610 --> 00:19:21,890
You think anything I left out?

358
00:19:21,890 --> 00:19:24,590
Nope.
Just remember as much as you can.

359
00:19:24,590 --> 00:19:29,530
You can actually go and register, just for
a free account right now at the PMI, and

360
00:19:29,530 --> 00:19:32,490
that way you can get access at
least to some of those articles.

361
00:19:32,490 --> 00:19:33,780
They're not gonna give
you access to everything,

362
00:19:33,780 --> 00:19:36,950
but it's a great resource for
you to actually begin in.

363
00:19:36,950 --> 00:19:40,810
And so once it asks you to do that, that
will again get you familiar with a lot of

364
00:19:40,810 --> 00:19:46,710
the terms and concepts to begin there,
and look forward to again.

365
00:19:46,710 --> 00:19:49,960
Seeing what else you actually have
available to you and the way that it

366
00:19:49,960 --> 00:19:53,860
actually opens doors in the future for
you as well, once you're PMP certified.

367
00:19:53,860 --> 00:19:55,390
And I do wanna throw out one more thing,

368
00:19:55,390 --> 00:19:57,850
it was the thing I was
thinking of a moment ago.

369
00:19:57,850 --> 00:20:02,020
In a lot of our shows, we go really
in depth into our content, and

370
00:20:02,020 --> 00:20:04,520
we talk about everything
that's gonna be on the exam.

371
00:20:04,520 --> 00:20:08,970
And what we try to do, is we try to make
it where our show contains everything you

372
00:20:08,970 --> 00:20:10,760
need to know for the exam.

373
00:20:10,760 --> 00:20:13,340
Well, with the PMP we'll do the same, so

374
00:20:13,340 --> 00:20:17,580
no different from any other show,
but it is so much information.

375
00:20:17,580 --> 00:20:22,800
There is so much, and a lot of it is kind
of open to interpretation in some cases.

376
00:20:22,800 --> 00:20:24,310
But this is one of the few cases,

377
00:20:24,310 --> 00:20:27,820
where I really do recommend
that you purchase a textbook.

378
00:20:27,820 --> 00:20:32,280
A book to use kind of in conjunction
with our videos is really handy,

379
00:20:32,280 --> 00:20:35,250
really helps to make sure that you've
got a good understanding of the content.

380
00:20:35,250 --> 00:20:38,685
And there's one book in
particular that I recommend, and

381
00:20:38,685 --> 00:20:41,290
I don't make any money on this or
anything.

382
00:20:41,290 --> 00:20:43,356
So, I'm just going straight to Amazon.

383
00:20:43,356 --> 00:20:47,872
And on amazon.com they
have this book here.

384
00:20:47,872 --> 00:20:49,974
It's written by Joseph Phillips.

385
00:20:49,974 --> 00:20:51,067
The author.
It's the CAPM,

386
00:20:51,067 --> 00:20:53,220
PMP all-in-one certification guide.

387
00:20:53,220 --> 00:20:56,050
Remember what I said at the beginning
of this little special is,

388
00:20:56,050 --> 00:21:00,280
you study the same way for both
certifications, so it's just one book.

389
00:21:00,280 --> 00:21:01,660
And it's a really good book.

390
00:21:01,660 --> 00:21:06,906
It's big, but he takes all the data and
he puts it into a logical order,

391
00:21:06,906 --> 00:21:11,080
it's very well written,
very easy to understand.

392
00:21:11,080 --> 00:21:12,300
It has a CD in the back,

393
00:21:12,300 --> 00:21:15,250
it has some practice questions
as well as a PDF of the book.

394
00:21:15,250 --> 00:21:18,650
So, it's just an all
around good book to use.

395
00:21:18,650 --> 00:21:22,100
So, if you're gonna buy just
one book I recommend this one.

396
00:21:22,100 --> 00:21:23,960
It's only $30 and hardcover.

397
00:21:23,960 --> 00:21:28,700
I bought the Kindle edition a while back,
and that's under $30 also.

398
00:21:28,700 --> 00:21:31,970
So, it's definitely something
that you can make use of.

399
00:21:31,970 --> 00:21:35,430
And it's a really good one, especially for
taking notes and kinda following along,

400
00:21:35,430 --> 00:21:38,050
it's pretty handy.

401
00:21:38,050 --> 00:21:40,620
So, that's about all I've got for the PMP.

402
00:21:40,620 --> 00:21:45,230
So, if you have any questions,
just feel free to reach out to us.

403
00:21:45,230 --> 00:21:46,965
We've got the Q&A section on the website,
or

404
00:21:46,965 --> 00:21:48,663
you can always shoot us an email or
whatever?

405
00:21:48,663 --> 00:21:51,297
But, hopefully that kind of answers
any questions you had about

406
00:21:51,297 --> 00:21:52,482
the certification itself.

407
00:21:52,482 --> 00:21:54,166
Now we're ready for the show.

408
00:21:54,166 --> 00:21:55,047
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don go over some of the details of the Project Management Professional Exam Update for January 2016.  They highlight the reasons for the change and show it differentiates from the current exam iteration.
episodes.title: 2016 Exam Update

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don introduce the viewer to the Project Management Institute (PMI) framework for managing projects. They take a look at the Project Management Body Knowledge and cover some required terminology for the exam.
episodes.title: Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don break down the five phases and ten knowledge groups of a project. They then introduce the viewer to project management processes and take a look at how to inputs, tool and techniques, and outputs are arranged according to the Project Management Institute.
episodes.title: Fundamentals Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don explain the layout of the PMBOK which is a resource available when joining PMI. They also begin explaining the initiating the project management process. Emphasis is given to describing the project management constraints, the Project Management Process--beginning to end, and briefly talk about Project Management Charter and the authority it gives to the project.
episodes.title: Initiation Phase

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a deeper look in how to develop a project management charter and identify the stakeholders. They show the breakdown on how to develop the project charter and how identify the stakeholders. They show some of the templates that can be used to help complete the initiation phase.
episodes.title: Initiation Phase Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin to tackle the most detailed phase of project management, the planning phase. They begin by talking about the purpose of developing a plan and why we need it. The project management plan is the result of developing how to manage the constraints of project time, project costs, project requirements and stakeholders.
episodes.title: Planning Part 1

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce the knowledge area of Project Scope Planning. Understanding the scope of project must be measureable, attainable and manageable which can only happen if the scope is clearly defined during the planning phase.
episodes.title: Planning Project Scope

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to plan the project scope and statement using the templates. They emphasize the need and parameters that make up the project scope. The scope statement will be used to help define the success of the project.
episodes.title: Planning Project Scope Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to define the scope of determining the requirements of the project. These are the deliverables that we will expect at the end of the project. They talk about how to make sure you can determine these requirements.
episodes.title: Determining Requirements

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin to cover the largest topic within the planning phase--scheduling the project. They show some of the templates used and show some basic Project Management Scheduling Utilities that can be used to help with project time management. They talk about defining the activities, sequencing the events and assigning resources to activities.
episodes.title: Time Management Part 1

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don they show the process of estimating the duration of activities within a project. They use different project management software to show how the duration of activities affect the overall duration of the project as well. They show the most common methods of estimating durations and describe the critical path and demonstrate how to determine it.
episodes.title: Time Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take the outputs of the activities planning, duration estimates and resource assignments to develop a schedule to manage the project. They show how the project plan can be compressed and adjusted to fit the project scope.
episodes.title: Time Management Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at the area of cost management for the project. They talk about some of the techniques used to create a budget for the project. They review all the relevant tools and techniques to estimate material and labor cost. They end the show with determining the budget for the project.
episodes.title: Cost Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss how to handle quality management, resources and communications. They describe the how to manage quality control and quality assurance. They take a look into the subject area of planning for materials and labor management. Then Ronnie and Don talk about how to manage the communication paths and communication methods to be used during the project execution.
episodes.title: Quality, Resources & Comms

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin the process of Risk Management within Project Management. They use the concepts of risk tolerance: risk adverse, risk seekers and risk neutral as base for risk management of the project. They also talk about the tools and techniques used to identify risks. They describe performing qualitative and quantitative risk analysis before project execution begins. They finish the risk management planning by taking a look into the risk response planning.
episodes.title: Planning for Risks

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at areas procurement management. They focus on contract execution, fulfillment and termination. They also show the most common contract types. Included in the episode are the concepts of stakeholder management and dealing with the motivations and agendas of stakeholders.
episodes.title: Procurements and Stakeholders

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin the next phase of project management. They talk about the transition into the monitoring and controlling while the project is being executed and work packages are being accomplished. They describe the need to direct and manage the project rather than micro managing every aspect of the project. They talk about using Project Management Information Systems to see the big picture while the project is being executed.
episodes.title: Execution Part 1

episodes.description: In this special episode, Don and the ITProTV team show the project planning phase of the team project--The arcade game cabinet. You see the use of project task assignments, the estimation of duration and costs as the team discusses talk about details of the project and the WBS are assigned for action on this project!
episodes.title: Developing a Plan

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don discuss the execution phase of a project. They start with the direct and manage project work process. They discuss performing the quality assurance methods that were defined during the planning phase. They wrap up the show discussing how to manage a project team.
episodes.title: Executing Part 1

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce the last few executing processes. They describe the tools and techniques used to manage communication during the project execution and what is needed to get contracts working during the project. The finish the show describing keeping the Stakeholders engaged with the project.
episodes.title: Executing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don start next phase of Project Management: the Monitoring and Controlling phase. They talking about the importance of setting good controls in place to facilitate project work. Also, the guys emphasize the controls to help out with change management. They end the show talking about keeping scope creep out of the project.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Controlling

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don give an overview of controlling time management and cost within the project. This episode demonstrates that within a project the close ties between cost, time and scope.
episodes.title: Schedule and Cost Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show the most common formulas found in the PMBOK and demonstrate how they are used when having to do forecasting for time and cost management within a project. They use the formulas in context of a project, emphasizing the need to memorize these for the PMP exam. The formula sheets Don uses in this episode are available for download bundled in a ZIP file. The download URL can be found in the Overview episode description.
episodes.title: Earned Value Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take us through the final work knowledge areas of controlling quality, communications, risks, procurements and stakeholders. Identifying the importance of keeping current and up to date while the project is executing and while receiving work progress reports so that good decisions can be made to keep the project on time, on scope and on budget.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Controlling Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don guide through some of the most common methodologies used in process management.  These processes include the Six Sigma, Lean and Kanban methods use wildly in project management. Project Managers may be directly involved in implementing these but should be aware.
episodes.title: Process Analysis

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into the world of Best Practices and Standards.  They help us to differentiate them and talk about some of the standards organization that affect projects.
episodes.title: Process Analysis Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don finish the entire series on the PMP by taking a look the final 2 knowledge areas in the Closing Process Group: Closing the Project or Phase and Closing the Procurements. The last phase is often overlooked but its importance shouldn't be underestimated. It is here we ensure the stakeholder satisfaction, release project teams to other projects and terminate contracts.
episodes.title: Closing

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into the project management tasks found the January 2016 objectives for the PMP exam.  The describe the tasks, skills and techniques and the processes that Project Managers should know and use in their Projects.
episodes.title: Project Management Tasks

episodes.description: In this example, Ronnie and Don review the Critical Path Method to determine Critical Path. They review the formula used to determine float and the method used to determine starts and finishes of each task.  Taking a single example, they start from just the duration and name of a task and show how to calculate simple forward pass and backward pass.  They determine the float and free float as well.
episodes.title: CPM Example Number 1

episodes.description: In this example, Ronnie and Don take another example that is a little more complex when the forward path has multiple predecessors.  This add complexity to determine the critical path. They show the calculation of the forward pass must be determined based on latest of the Early Finish between multiple predecessors.  They also determine the float for each task
episodes.title: CPM Example Number 2

episodes.description: In this example, Ronnie and Don show another example.  In this example, Don and Ronnie show how determining the critical path helps answer multiple types of questions that a PMP candidate may be expected to answer.  They emphasize the key to success will be math and practice of the techniques shown in this series of examples.
episodes.title: CPM Example Number 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a closer look at how to face the challenge of determining the Earned Value.  They begin with establishing the importance of the PV, Planned Value.  Don shows the basic formulas and then sets it it the context of questions.  The guys demonstrate how to take the given information to determine the EV of a given scenario.  Working through the scenarios, they show us how the Earned Value represent the value at a specific point in time helping us see where were should be at any given time in our project vs where we are.
episodes.title: Earned Value

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss how to determine Schedule Performance.  The Schedule Performance helps us to determine whether we are ahead of schedule based on time, deliverables or even cost.  The determination of the SPI tells us how much we can be ahead or behind schedule and  provide an indicator of where Project Mangers may need to act to bring a project back on schedule, according to the guys.  They show some of the most common types of questions likely encountered by a PMP candidate.
episodes.title: Schedule Performance

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to look at different formulas, this time focus on Cost  Performance.  Using the basic formula, Don shows how to determine what we’ve spent in comparison to what we expected to spend.  This will give us the Cost Variance. Along with the CV, they show how to get the CPI, the cost performance index too.  This is will help when we compare it against another part of the project to help us understand whether we’re over budget or under budget at that particular point in time.
episodes.title: Cost Performance

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don talk about the Cumulative Indexes that allow us to determine whether we are ahead of schedule or behind schedule, under budget or over up to the time you run these formulas.  This will allow you to take a historical look at the project’s cost and schedule performance up to that point.  Don shows how to calculate both and reminds us to watch out for unusual figures that can cause some issues.
episodes.title: Cumulative Performance

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don dive into schedule and budget forecasting formulas.  They begin by addressing the issue of using an ETC, estimate to completion formula.  We learn why we would use it and how you’re likely to see it on the exam.  Don also then shows us that result of this formula is helpful when determining the TCPI, To Completion Cost Performance Index.  Using these formulas will help us to forecast what we expect to need in comparison to the Budget at Completion (BAC).  They also can show us that we can use the TCPI to forecast based on current rate of expenditures.
episodes.title: Forecasting
